item.title: Rocks
item.description:
I knew I liked rocks, and I knew I liked bouldering, but my love for both has been lifted to new heights after my stay in Fontainebleau. My initial plan was to spend around 3 days here, do some hiking in the woods and maybe climb a bit if the stars aligned. I ended up staying 12 days and climbing more than I could have imagined.

Now entering Fontainebleau.

12 Nights in Regina

For Regina, this stay was the next big test, but I must say she did marvelous! Through rain, wind and snow she kept straight and dry. Some moisture on the insides now and then, but that is to be expected. In short, I couldn't have wished for a better tent.


Good girl

My bike on the other hand was becoming more and more of a problem. It had started to become very hard to turn the pedals. The owner of the hostel was friendly enough to lend me his tools and after some tinkering I discovered one of the bearings in the back wheel was completely shattered.

I spent nearly every evening trying to get the thing working properly but in the end the best I could do was get it to a point where both wheels were spinning again. How long this bike will last remains to be seen. To be continued I am sure...

Discovering Fontainebleau & outdoor climbing

Silly me thought I would explore the climbing area of Fontainebleau the first day and make up a planning according to my findings. It soon became clear that the climbing area is more like 100 climbing areas spread over the entire forest, each containing more boulders than you can count. In short, infinite possibilities...

This is a top down view of half of 1 climbing area called 'Eléphant'.
This is La forêt de Larchant, the piece of the forest containing the Eléphant site.
This is a map of the forest of Fontainebleau. I stayed in La Chapelle La Reine and climbed around n° 7 and n° 15. Much left to do as you can see.

My first few days were spent in the 'Eléphant' area. By the 3rd day I was feeling really good and my climbing was getting better. Unfortunately the day 3 curse struck and overconfidence kicked in. I took a bit of a nasty fall and hurt my right knee. For some reason I was able to keep climbing for the next couple of hours, but after that the pain really kicked in and a 2-day rest period was in order.

Next I hitch-hiked to the 'Canche aux Merciers' site, which was a bit further away from the hostel. Here I met some cool German guys who joined me on a route that was supposed to be easy but took us most of the afternoon to figure out.

My final days of climbing were spent with people I met at the hostel. This gave me a chance to try some of the harder routes as I now not only had people who could look after me but could also use their crashpad (a portable matras that softens your fall). Unfortunately my body was pretty much worn out after this much climbing in so little time. Next time!

2 of my fingers after 6 days of climbing. Easily the worst place for blisters if have ever experienced.

What follows is a large collection of pictures of rocks. If you don't like rocks (really?), I made a convenient little link to skip this part:

Skip the beautiful pictures of rocks

Made a wrong turn on day 1 and ended up here.
The rock on the left is called l'Elephant after which this area is named. It looks more like an elephant from the other side.
My first climbing buddy!

The rock is called 'Les fesses', the route is aptly called 'La fissure des fesses'. I spent more time with my fingers in this crack than I'm willing to admit.
This is were I fell. It could have been worse!
Canche aux Merciers, another area full of rocks.



Nature man...

Socializing!

On the second week of my stay in the hostel, a bunch of new people arrived. A couple of Germans, a couple of South-Koreans and 3 American guys studying in France for the semester. All really nice people and a good reminder why hostels can be awesome.

The German couple asked me if I wanted to join them on their visit to the Chateau of Fontainebleau on one of my off days. A bit awkward at times because the girl didn't understand a lot of English and my German is just bad (more like Dutch with k→ch and w→v) but all in all a very enjoyable day.

Front of the Chateau.
A room in the Chateau, looks better in real life...
View from window
This cabinet was actually really awesome. Very intricate design and beautifully ornamented.
The absurdly large gardens of the Chateau.

I also had quite an interesting talk with the male part of the Korean couple (we climbed together). They were on their 8th month of a year long journey, for which they had been saving for 3 years (since they got married). A lot of couples these days only meet at later stages in their lives, usually when they are both alreay working. As a result it is harder to really get to know each other when a big part of your lives is spent apart. So not only were they now learning to live together on a whole new level, they were also making the journey of their dreams.

Definitely some food for thought there...

Zean and Yil.

Departure

After 12 days I finally made the decision to leave this awesome place. The weather had taken a turn for the worse and all my new friends had left as well :(. I will definitely be coming back here some time in the future, but for now it is goodbye. On to new unknown places and hopefully be blown away again!

Packing the chicken broth I made the day before. This is how it's supposed to look, right?

Also this random picture of bread that I couldn't fit anywhere else:

Have you ever seen a loaf of bread this big??? Even Walter can't get over it.


Lessons Learned:

  • Fontainebleau is amazing and an infinite source of bouldering fun. Outdoor climbing feels so good.
  • South-Koreans count differently, eg. Zean was 32 years old in Europe, but 34 in South-Korea. How weird is that?
  • This bike should have been more thouroughly tested and checked before I left. Yes daddy, you were right again.

item.title: Naked
item.description:
To keep the cost of my stay in Paris within reasonable limits, I had searched for a place to stay through couchsurfing. The first person that replied to my couchsurfing request came with a disclaimer saying he lived the nudist lifestyle and his guests should be open to trying it themselves. This was definitely out of my comfort zone, but sometimes that can be a good thing which leads to fun experiences and new insights. Upon my arrival, I was pretty much the worst possible guest imaginable. I ate his food and his medicine, took a shower and crashed. It was necessary.

The next morning both my knees were hurting, the fever had turned into a full blown flu and my shoulders were still blocked. Dr. Google told me the kneepain was a generic case of "Runner's knee", which would be resolved by taking inflammatory medicine, resting and stop being a little bitch. Luckily over the course of my stay the pain slowly subsided. The flu lasted for about 4 days, kept in check by a daily dose of Paracetamol. And finally the shoulders were just a bad case of sore muscles that faded by the end of the week. So my stay in Paris was pretty much a drug fueled tourist trip, the best kind of tourist trip.

Oh look, a church!
Visit to the museum of space and aviation, Belgian Military plane from WW I. Let's all take a moment here and realize these guys were shooting at each other from planes made of bamboo...

The Louvre was the first place that really blew me away. I generally have a hard time enjoying art, mostly due to my limited knowledge of it. However, my expectations were exceeded the moment I stepped into the courtyard of this epic museum. A big shoutout to the audioguides because they were just perfect. Hard to explain but truly an enjoyable experience that I would recommend to everybody. I also may or may not have felt emotions about art once or twice during my visit. Am I a hipster now?

Anyway, I snapped some great pictures while I was there

Cupid reviving Psyche, a beautiful marble sculpture. A definite top 3.
Fat bourgeoisie guy, forgot his name. I should buy a selfie stick...
La Joconde aka. Mona Lisa. It was not busy at all so I got a chance to see it nice and close without too much problems.
Liberty leading the People, also a personal favourite.
The Venus of Milo
My reward after a long day of art

Another pleasant suprise was my tourist tour of the city of Paris. In 3rd grade my high school organized a 1-day blitz visit to Paris for our french class. I don't remember much of it, which means it mustn't have been that impressive. With this in mind I set out to see some buildings and stuff and my prejudiced brain was again proven wrong.

La Promenade Plantée, a beautiful stroke of green in an otherwise quite gray city. Must be even nicer in summer.
Probably the best picture ever taken of the Notre Dame.
The Pantheon, too bad it was undergoing renovations.
Beautiful corinthian colums... No I didn't look that up, shut up.
A mosque, because I am religiously unbiased
Hey look, I am not the only person crazy enough to sleep in a tent this time of year!
L'Arc de Triomphe, holy shit that thing is massive!
The Eiffel Tower, holy shit that thing is even more massive!
A nice sunset view from a small parc right next to/beneath the Eiffel Tower

Especially those last two were way more impressive than I remembered from my last visit. Sorry I doubted you, Paris...

The rest of my stay was a combination of cooking for my host (unfortunately his anus did not handle my chili too well), resting my body, watching classic french movies, a three guy butt-naked party (no body fluids were exchanged), vin rouge, pain et fromage and of course trying to get my bike fixed (did not work). Pascal (my hosts name) offered to let me stay for 2 days longer than planned so I could really shake all the fever and fatigue, big thanks for that! Unfortunately I forgot to take any pictures of him, but I guess they would have needed some heavy blurring anyway.

Leaving Paris after 6 days felt a bit weird. It's funny how fast you become attached to these places...

Also, the day before I arrived was the day of the Charlie Hebdo attacks. I saw the events unfold from the city where it was happening and saw it almost through French eyes. I decided not to join the big manifestation as I would have felt a bit out of place, but I did enjoy the massive crowd going home by metro, so theres that. Anyway, I guess this is mandatory:




Lessons Learned:

  • Novel ways of dealing with the last drop when you can't rely on underpants
  • Nudity does not always have to be associated with sex. It is sometimes also just a lot more comfortable than keeping these stupid clothes on
  • Paris is a really cool city, for some reason I always played it down in my mind until now

In Memoriam

Apparently my cat was hit by a car last week. Her second encounter with a hrududu, only this time she did not manage to escape death :(

By sheer dumb luck, I happened to have made a short video of her a week before my departure while she was acting a bit crazy with my tent bag. So this is in remembrance of Stars, the best cat that ever lived. I'll miss you...

item.title: Champagne
item.description:
After my first night there, I decided to stay in Reims for another day to explore the city and tinker with my bike. The saddle had been sliding down during the last 2 days and by now I was practically riding a childrens bike.

Reims turned out to be a fairly nice city with some beautiful buildings, the most notable of course being the cathedral.

The only angle that didn't include ugly scaffolding

The other side of the city, which is just a 1-minute bikeride from the center, was a bit less impressive. Most of the streets and buildings had decayed quite heavily and the people seemed pretty unhappy in general. Les banlieues? It got me thinking about wealth and freedom and made me a bit sad. Heavy stuff!

On a more positive note, I made my first travel buddy on my second night in Reims. An extremely helpful French guy who gave me my first real conversation since starting this journey, some sound travel advice and lended me a bunch of tools he had lying about in his car so I could fix my bike (didn't work, hurt my thumb). Also, for reasons unknown, he assumed I did not know what a bundling rope was and went to great heights to explain the intricate details of this novel invention.

Phuc, I was tired

Next morning was the start of my second attempt to test my multi-day hiking skills. The plan was to hike/bike from Reims to the city of Meaux over the course of 3 days. From there it would be relatively cheap to take the train to Paris. Sounded great!

Day 1 was beautiful, but unfortunately mostly covered in mist (apparently the French weather guys are just as bad at predicting the weather). After about 1 hour of biking the Google Maps routeplanner decided to fuck me over and stop working, so I had to improvise and take a different route. This ended up being a slight detour, but probably way more scenic than my original route.

Just a French church I guess
Creepy, misty graveyard in the middle of nowhere
A beautiful village covered in mist
Champagne much?
For some reason, French churches are so much cooler than Belgian churches
One of these in every village I came through today

By the time I reached my endpoint for the day, Mareuil-le-Port, it had been dark for a good 30 minutes, my shoulders and upper back were completely blocked an my right knee hurt quite a bit. My body sucks... I decided to hit up the local drug dealer and get some of the good stuff*, hoping the pain would be gone by the next morning. I spent my first night with Regina (which is how I have decided to name my tent) in a small public park right next to the Marne.

Day 2 started with some drizzle and mist, only slightly less pain than the evening before and an epic wrong turn which led me through some pretty muddy fields (which fucked up my bike even more). This day was also quite boring as far as views go.

Lowest hanging mistletoe I've ever seen
Godlike pain au trois chocolats to lift my spirits
Belgium represent
Pretty ruins of a French church, more mistletoe
My companion throughout most of this day: The Marne

The pain in my knees and back had again been steadily increasing throughout the day and by the end were accompanied by a slight fever, yet somehow I still managed to arrive in Charly-sur-Marne before sunset. After wasting 2 more hours waiting for the darkness I found another small park on the outskirts of town and checked out for the day.

At around 3 in the morning, my night's rest was interrupted by what sounded like someone firing a gun right next to me. I was scared like a little bitch, very tired and it was cold outside, so I decided against taking a peak and went back to sleep. The next morning did bring me an explanation:

This bike man...

With the help of a friendly bypasser and his tools, changing the tire only took me the better part of an hour. After 2 more hours of uphill walking, which by this time would better classified as limping, I came by the sign that meant the end of my woes.

Cheap-ass trains, here I come

Since trains within the Île de France region are cheap, I decided the long-term survival of my knees was more important than my ego and headed over to the nearest station instead of continuing to Meaux (still 20km left). After an hour of feeling like a massive bum taking a train with the shittiest and dirtiest of bikes, I finally arrived in the City of Love.

So the results of this second test:

  • Wrecked my right knee (unable to put my full body weight + backpack on it)
  • A medicated fever (I assumed this was a fatigue fever)
  • The inability to look sideways due to upper back pains
  • Mentally and physically exhausted
  • Didn't achieve my goal

This is going great! Why didn't anybody tell me this was going to be hard?

* Ibuprofen

Lessons Learned:

  • A bundling rope is a device to tie stuff to your bike's baggage rack. You attach it to the iron platelets on either side of the bike using the hooks and put your stuff under the rope.
  • Google Maps is not to be trusted.
  • More extensive testing of the bike is required before embarking on such a journey.
  • Sleeping in a tent for multiple days without having a place to relax for a bit is no fun

item.title: Meuse
item.description:
I reached my mental and physical limits after one day of backpacking. A pretty big hit to my self-confidence and morale, but I was still determined enough to make it work. Some changes in mindset were needed though.

First point of business was of course to dry my gear, in particular the soaking wet walking shoes. I shared a room with another lazy, workophobic traveller such as myself (only this guy was Walloon, which makes it worse*). He was able to tell me the heating, while making a shitload of noise during the night, did not actually work. Additionally, the hostel would start their yearly holiday period the next day, so I would not be able to stay longer if my stuff wasn't dry yet. Great!

New plan:

  1. Check out the Valley of the Meuse, which was the entire reason I wanted to come to Namen.
  2. Get to the nearest hostel on my route as quickly as possible in a way that would not be too taxing on my body (this was apparently in Reims, some 200km away)
  3. Check out Reims, dry gear and setup for a 3 day hike through the Champagne Region to Paris


1. Valley of the Meuse

Made my way over to the "Viaduc de la Beez" in the Valley of the Meuse. Took some pics and got some weird moisture in the corner of my eyes (probably from the mist, yea that must've been it).

Viaduc de la Beez on the right
First beautiful rock formation
Rocks in the mist
The walking/biking track next to the Meuse
Small harbour overlooked by the rocks
More rocks that did something special to my heart
And it goes on... But I had to head back :(

Definitely something worth revisiting with friends on a sunnier day! I think it would make for a great day-long bike ride.

This little trip completely lifted my spirits and was so worth making the detour through Namen. But now it was time to say goodbye and head over to La Douce France!

Getting to Reims

I conjured a route that minimized my train costs, didn't deviate too much from my original planned route, only required me to bike for 15km this day and would hopefully still give me some nice nature views:

Namen ---<TRAIN>--- Virton ---<BIKE 15km>--- Montmédy ---<TRAIN>--- Reims

Riding my bike across the border

I had to wait 2 hours for my train to arrive in Montmédy, so had some time to explore and discover the local stronghold town on a hill

Took a shitty picture against the sunlight, so it required some editing :).
The view of Montmédy en-route to the stronghold





Pretty cool. Afterwards took the train to Reims, found the CIS hostel (which was 40% off for some reason) and fell asleep immediately after eating my dinner. A good day!

* Source: http://www.n-va.be/verkiezingen/programma

Lessons Learned:

  • There aren't that many hostels in the Ardennen region, nor in France.
  • I can take my bike on the trains in France for free!
  • The CIS hostels spread around France have a special 2015 price, only costing €14 a night.

item.title: Start
item.description:
My journey started on the 3rd of January in Brussels. Upon opening the front door, I was greeted by a moderate drizzle, but the weather forecast had assured me this would clear up by noon. After doing a little tourist tour around Brussels/discovering the joys of searching for the GR trail markings, making my first stop at a local coffee shop and saying my final goodbyes to two friends who had joined me up to this point, I was all by myself.

The weather did not improve by noon. It made crossing the Zoniënwoud an... interesting experience. The rain subdued for a little while after my emerging from the forest, only to return with renewed force not half an hour later. After 6 hours of cycling and walking in the rain, I was wet to the core and my morale was already at a low point. The sun was setting and I had yet to encounter any potential accommodation (obviously tent was not a feasible option at this point). Things got real a lot quicker than I expected...

A nice place to watch the sunset and feel the panic flooding into your brain!

At that point I probably made the best decision of the day: Fuck the GR routes, head over to the nearest town and find myself a safe haven to regroup. The nearest hostel was in Namen (my planned goal of the day, but at this point still a good 40km away), so I rode my bike to the nearest train station and took the next train there.

After recovering my soaked underpants from halfway up my ass, the best low-power-shower in recent memory and a cold beer, I was ready to reconsider my route and planning. All in all not the best way to start a six month journey, and maybe I could have prevented some of these things, but then again, experience is the best teacher.

Lessons Learned:

  • I cannot bike 70km in one day with this pack on my back
  • If rain is a possibility, have accomodation plans in advance and have a backup plan
  • GR routes are not made for bycicles
  • My gear is waterproof, but not after an entire day of rain
